title: Lesson 16: Separation Technique - Chromatography
content:
Lesson 16: Separation Technique - Chromatography

The Art of Color Writing: Revealing the Hidden Secrets in a Drop of Ink!

Is black ink really just black?

If you put a single dot of black ink on a piece of paper and dip the paper in water, something amazing happens. The black dot begins to spread and separate into a rainbow of hidden colors! This isn't magic; it's a powerful scientific technique that can "un-mix" colors. How does this happen, and what can this color race tell us about a substance?

Chromatography: The "Color Race"

The word chromatography comes from the Greek words 'chroma' (meaning color) and 'graphein' (meaning to write). It's a technique used to separate different components of a solution, like the different colored dyes mixed together in ink.

Think of it as a race. All the colors start at the same line, but some are faster than others. As they "race" along a surface (like paper), they spread out, and we can see each individual color. This method is so sensitive it can separate substances that are dissolved and look like a single color.

The Key Players in the Race

For this race to happen, we need two important things:

1. The Stationary Phase (The Racetrack)

This is the surface that the colors race on. It doesn't move. In simple paper chromatography, this is the filter paper.

2. The Mobile Phase (The Pusher)

This is the liquid (or gas) that moves and pushes the colors along the racetrack. It is also called the solvent. For separating ink, this is usually water.

Why Do The Colors Separate?

The secret behind the separation is a competition between two properties:

  • Solubility (Ability to travel): How well a color dissolves in the mobile phase (water). Colors that are more soluble travel faster and farther up the paper.
  • Adsorption (Stickiness): How strongly a color "sticks" to the stationary phase (paper). Colors that are more "sticky" travel slower and don't go as far.

The component that is more soluble in the solvent and less sticky to the paper wins the race!

How to Do Paper Chromatography

1. Prepare the Paper

Draw a pencil line on a filter paper strip and put a small dot of ink in the center of the line.

2. Set up the Beaker

Suspend the paper in a beaker with a solvent (like water), making sure the ink dot is above the water level.

3. Watch the Race

The water will rise up the paper (by capillary action) and carry the dyes with it at different speeds.

4. See the Result

Once dry, the paper will show different colored spots. This final paper is called a chromatogram.

Lesson Summary: Chromatography

What It Does

Separates dissolved components of a mixture, like the dyes in ink.

The Principle

Components travel at different speeds based on their solubility and "stickiness" to the paper.

The Phases

Stationary phase (paper) and Mobile phase (solvent).

Applications

Forensics, separating pigments from plants, identifying drugs.
questions:
Lesson 16: Questions on Chromatography

1. The word "Chromatography" comes from Greek words meaning "color writing." What is this technique used for, and why is it so powerful for separating mixtures like ink?

Answer:

What it's used for:
Chromatography is a laboratory technique used to separate the different components (solutes) that are dissolved in a solution.

Why it's so powerful:
Its power comes from its ability to separate substances that are very similar and are mixed together in the same solution. Even if a drop of ink looks like a single black color, chromatography can reveal all the different colored dyes hidden within it. It works even with very small amounts of a substance.

2. In paper chromatography, we need a "racetrack" and a "pusher." What are the scientific names for these two parts, and what do we typically use for each when separating ink?

Answer:

Step 1: The Racetrack (The part that stays still).
The scientific name for this is the Stationary Phase. In our ink experiment, the stationary phase is the filter paper.

Step 2: The Pusher (The part that moves).
The scientific name for this is the Mobile Phase. It's the solvent that moves up the paper. In our ink experiment, the mobile phase is usually water.

3. Imagine a "color race" on a piece of filter paper. What two properties of a dye determine how fast it moves up the paper and "wins" the race?

Answer:

The speed of a dye in chromatography depends on a competition between two properties:

  • Solubility in the mobile phase: How well the dye dissolves in the solvent (e.g., water). A more soluble dye will travel faster and farther.
  • Adsorption (stickiness) to the stationary phase: How strongly the dye sticks to the paper. A less "sticky" dye will travel faster and farther.

So, the dye that is the most soluble and least sticky wins the race!

4. Look at the final chromatogram below. Which colored spot (A or B) represents the dye that is MORE soluble in the water? Explain your answer.

Answer:

Spot A represents the more soluble dye.

Reasoning:
In chromatography, the solvent (mobile phase) moves from the bottom of the paper to the top. It carries the dissolved dyes with it. The dyes that are more soluble in the solvent will be carried along for a longer distance up the paper. Since spot A has traveled the farthest from the start line, it must be the most soluble component.

5. In an experiment to separate the dyes in ink, why must the spot of ink be placed *above* the level of the water in the beaker?

Answer:

The ink spot must be placed above the water level so that the ink does not simply dissolve directly into the water at the bottom of the beaker.

The Correct Process:
The water needs to rise up the paper by capillary action and then reach the ink spot. This allows the water to gradually pick up the dyes and carry them up the paper, causing them to separate. If the ink spot starts in the water, it will just form a colored solution in the beaker, and no separation will happen on the paper.

6. What is the name of the paper strip after the separation is complete and the different colored spots are visible?

Answer:

The paper strip showing the separated components is called a chromatogram.

7. A student performs paper chromatography on a drop of green leaf extract. They see a green spot and a yellow spot. What does this tell you about the pigments in the green leaf?

Answer:

This result tells us that the green color in the leaf is not from a single substance. It is a mixture of at least two different colored substances (pigments).

  • There is a green pigment (chlorophyll).
  • There is also a yellow pigment (like carotenoid) that was hidden by the green color.

8. Chromatography is used in forensic labs. How could a detective use this technique to find out if a suspect's pen was used to write a ransom note?

Answer:

Step 1: Create a Chromatogram for Both Inks.
The detective would take a small sample of the ink from the ransom note and a sample of ink from the suspect's pen. They would then perform chromatography on both samples separately, under the exact same conditions.

Step 2: Compare the Results.
They would compare the two resulting chromatograms. Each ink has a unique "fingerprint" of colored dyes. If the number of colored spots, their colors, and the distances they traveled are identical for both the note's ink and the suspect's pen, it is strong evidence that the suspect's pen was used.

9. Fill in the blanks: In chromatography, the component that is more soluble in the ______ phase and less adsorbed to the ______ phase travels faster and farther up the paper.

Answer:

In chromatography, the component that is more soluble in the mobile phase and less adsorbed to the stationary phase travels faster and farther up the paper.

10. A student performs chromatography on a red ink pen and only sees one red spot travel up the paper. What can the student conclude about this red ink?

Answer:

Since only one red spot appeared and it did not separate into other colors, the student can conclude that the red ink is likely a pure substance (a single dye) and not a mixture of different colored dyes.
exercises:
Lesson 16: Exercises on Chromatography

1. Match the Terms: Match the term in Column A with its correct description or example in Column B.

Column A (Term)

  • Chromatography
  • Stationary Phase
  • Mobile Phase
  • Chromatogram

Column B (Description)

  • A. The solvent that moves (e.g., water).
  • B. The paper strip showing the separated colors.
  • C. The "racetrack" that doesn't move (e.g., filter paper).
  • D. A technique to separate dissolved components of a mixture.

Correct Matches:

1 → D,   2 → C,   3 → A,   4 → B

2. Spot the Mistake: A student sets up a chromatography experiment as shown below. What is the one critical mistake they have made?

Answer:

The mistake is that the ink spot is submerged in the solvent (water). The ink will just dissolve into the water at the bottom instead of being carried up the paper. The ink spot should always be placed above the solvent level.

3. Which Will Win the Race? A mixture contains two dyes, Dye X and Dye Y.

  • Dye X is very soluble in water but doesn't stick to the paper well.
  • Dye Y is not very soluble in water and sticks to the paper very strongly.

Which dye will travel farther up the paper?

Answer:

Dye X will travel farther up the paper.

Reasoning: The fastest component is the one that is most soluble in the mobile phase (water) and least adsorbed (sticky) to the stationary phase (paper). Dye X fits both these criteria, so it will "win the race."

4. Application Station: Which of the following tasks is an actual application of chromatography?

  • a) Separating cream from milk.
  • b) Separating drugs from a blood sample.
  • c) Separating iron pins from sand.
  • d) Separating salt from sea water.

Answer:

The correct choice is b) Separating drugs from a blood sample.

Reasoning: Chromatography is excellent at separating tiny amounts of dissolved substances. It is widely used in forensics and medicine to detect and separate different chemical compounds in body fluids like blood or urine.

5.Why a Pencil? In a chromatography experiment, why is it important to draw the starting line with a pencil and not a pen?

Answer:

Pencil lead is made of graphite, which is insoluble in water. If you used a pen, the ink from the line itself would also separate into its component colors, confusing the results of the experiment.

6.True or False: Chromatography can only be used to separate colored substances.

Answer:

False. While it's great for colored substances, advanced chromatography techniques can separate colorless substances too. The separated components can be made visible later by spraying them with a special chemical (a locating agent) or using UV light.

7.Fill in the Blanks: The principle of chromatography is that different substances dissolved in the same solvent are adsorbed to a different extent on the same ________ phase.

Answer:

...on the same stationary phase.

8.Creative Thinking: A company wants to know if a competitor is using the same secret formula for their purple grape drink. What experiment could they perform on the two drinks to compare them?

Answer:

They could perform paper chromatography on both drinks. If the resulting chromatograms (the pattern of separated colors) are identical, it is very likely that they use the same mixture of food dyes in their formula.

9.Analogy Challenge: Filter paper is to the Stationary Phase as ________ is to the Mobile Phase.

Answer:

Water (or any suitable solvent)

10.Why does the water move up the paper against gravity in a chromatography experiment?

Answer:

The water moves up the paper due to a phenomenon called capillary action. This is the ability of a liquid to flow in narrow spaces without the assistance of, or even in opposition to, external forces like gravity.

11.What if it's not water? An ink is insoluble in water but soluble in alcohol. What should you use as the mobile phase to separate its components?

Answer:

You should use alcohol as the mobile phase. The chosen solvent must be one in which the components of the mixture are soluble.

12.Purity Check: A scientist is trying to determine if a new blue dye is a pure substance or a mixture. How can chromatography help?

Answer:

The scientist can perform chromatography on the blue dye. If it separates into multiple colored spots, it's a mixture. If it moves up the paper as a single, un-separated blue spot, it is likely a pure substance.

13.Identify the Technique: You are given a solution containing several different dissolved amino acids (which are colorless). What separation technique would be most suitable to separate them?

Answer:

Chromatography. It is the best technique for separating different substances that are dissolved together in the same solvent.

14.Which property is more important for a dye to travel far in chromatography: high solubility or low adsorption (stickiness)?

Answer:

Both are important, as it's the balance between them that determines the speed. However, for a dye to move at all, it must have some solubility in the mobile phase. A dye with high solubility and low stickiness will travel the farthest.

15.Choose the Best Separation Method: To separate the different pigments in a flower petal extract, which method would you choose?

a) Filtration
b) Evaporation
c) Chromatography
d) Sublimation

Answer:

c) Chromatography. The different pigments are all dissolved together in the extract, making chromatography the ideal technique to separate them.
intros:
Lesson 16: Separation Technique - Chromatography

Discover a technique so powerful it can unravel the hidden colors in a single drop of ink. Let's see how a simple race on paper can solve chemical mysteries!

Intro 1: The Great Ink Race

Is black ink really just one color, or is it a secret mixture of many colors hiding together? How can we find out?

It turns out that most black inks are actually a mixture of several different colored dyes. To see them, we can use a clever technique called chromatography, which literally means "color writing." It’s like setting up a race for the colors on a paper racetrack!

We put a dot of ink on a strip of paper and dip the end in water. As the water creeps up the paper, it dissolves the ink and carries the different colored dyes along with it. Some colors are "faster" and travel farther up the paper, while others are "slower" and lag behind. This difference in speed separates the colors, revealing the true components of the ink.

Unraveling mixtures by seeing which color wins the race!

Intro 2: The Sticky Race

Imagine a race between three friends, but each one has different shoes. Who do you think would win?

Chromatography is a lot like this race. The "racetrack" is a special material, like paper, and the "runners" are the different colored dyes in a mixture. A liquid, like water, acts like a gust of wind pushing all the runners forward.

The separation happens because each colored dye has a different "stickiness" to the paper. The colors that are less sticky (like runner A with fast shoes) get pushed far and fast by the water. The colors that are very sticky (like runner C with sticky shoes) get held back by the paper and move very slowly. This difference in speed and stickiness spreads the colors out, separating them along the paper.

Separation is a race between sticking to the paper and flowing with the water!

Intro 3: Forensic Science

A mysterious note is found at a crime scene. Detectives find two suspect pens nearby. How can they prove which pen wrote the note?

The answer lies in chromatography! Every ink is a unique mixture of colored dyes, like a secret recipe. By using chromatography, forensic scientists can separate the colors in the ink from the note and create a unique pattern, like a fingerprint.

They then do the same thing for the ink from each suspect pen. The pen whose color pattern perfectly matches the pattern from the note is the one used to write it. It’s a powerful tool that uses the science of separating mixtures to solve real-world crimes.

Using a color fingerprint to solve the crime.

Intro 4: Unmixing Colors

If you mix blue and yellow paint, you get green. But is there a way to "un-mix" the green and get the blue and yellow back?

While you can't easily un-mix paint, you can un-mix colored dyes that are dissolved in a liquid! If green ink is made from blue and yellow dyes, we can use chromatography to separate them. The process acts like a filter, but a very special kind of filter that works on dissolved substances.

The key is that the blue dye and yellow dye will have different properties. One might be more soluble in water, or one might stick to the paper more strongly. These differences cause them to travel at different speeds as the water moves up the paper. The faster one pulls ahead, and the slower one falls behind, and soon the green ink has been "un-mixed" back into its original blue and yellow components.

The scientific method for taking colors apart.

Intro 5: Nature's Hidden Rainbow

A leaf looks green, but in the fall it turns yellow or orange. Were those colors hiding inside the green leaf the whole time?

Yes, they were! A green leaf contains several different types of pigments, which are the molecules that give it color. The most abundant pigment is chlorophyll, which is bright green. But hiding underneath are other pigments like carotenoids (which are yellow and orange).

Scientists use chromatography to prove this. They can crush a green leaf to get an extract, and then use chromatography to separate the different pigments. Just like with ink, the pigments race up the paper at different speeds, revealing bands of green, yellow, and orange. In the summer, the green chlorophyll is so strong it covers up the other colors. In autumn, the chlorophyll breaks down, allowing the beautiful hidden colors to finally be seen.

Using science to reveal the hidden rainbow in a single green leaf.
summary:
Lesson 16 Summary: Separation by Chromatography

Separating the components of a mixture in a colorful race.

The Principle

Chromatography is used to separate solutes that dissolve in the same solvent. The separation is based on the fact that different components travel at different speeds across a stationary phase (the paper), carried by a mobile phase (the solvent). The component that is more soluble in the solvent moves faster and further.

When to Use It

  • To separate different colors from a dye or ink.
  • To separate pigments from natural sources like flowers or leaves.
  • To separate drugs from a blood sample in forensic science.

Key Terminology

The paper is the stationary phase (it doesn't move), and the solvent is the mobile phase (it moves). This powerful technique can even separate components present in very small quantities.
